awd_titl_txt: Recent Developments on the Properties of Emergent Layered 2D Quantum Magnetic Materials and Heterostructures
awd_abstract_narration:
This proposal mainly seeks to partially support 18 undergraduate students, graduate students, post-docs, and under-represented, female, junior and retired faculty to attend and present at the symposium on Quantum and Topological materials at the Spring Materials Research Society (MRS) national meeting in Honolulu, Hawaii, May 8-13, 2022.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

MRS 2022 Spring Meeting

Recent Developments on the Properties of Emergent Layered 2D Quantum Magnetic Materials and Heterostructures

Symposium QT06

 

Objectives of the symposium

Of particular importance, this symposium focused on the recent advances in the design and fabrication of new 2D magnets and their heterostructures; their magneto-optical and magnetoelectric properties; novel techniques in nanoscale characterizations of 2D magnetic systems; theoretical developments and computational models. The material systems include atomically thin chromium trihalides, chalcogen-based van der Waals magnets (ferromagnets and antiferromagnets), twisted bilayer graphene, magnetic topological insulators (such as MnBi(2)Te(4)), and Weyl semimetals (such as Co(2)MnGa, Co(3)Sn(2)S(2,) etc.). This symposium's primary goal is to bring together both experimentalists and theoreticians investigating the physics, chemistry, materials science, and engineering aspects of magnetic quantum materials. With a mix of young scientists and established leaders in the field as invited and joint keynote speakers, the symposium will capture the new and most recent exciting developments in the field of quantum magnetism and simultaneously enable researchers to receive a more in-depth perception of this emerging field and its grand challenges and opportunities.

 

The symposium total attendance is 133 that includes the tutorial.

 

This symposium covered a wide variety of experimental probes such as spin polarized scanning tunneling microscopy, single spin magnetometry, scanning magnetic circular dichroism microscopy, second harmonic generation, and electron tunneling, and DFT and ab initio computational tools. In addition, on the recent advances in the design and fabrication of new 2D magnets and their heterostructures; their magneto-optical and magnetoelectric properties; novel techniques in nanoscale characterizations of 2D magnetic systems; theoretical developments and

computational models. With a mix of young scientists and established leaders in the field as invited speakers, the symposium captured the new and most impactful developments and simultaneously, enabled researchers to receive a deeper perception of this rich field and outline the grand challenges and opportunities. This symposium provided greater opportunity for underrepresented Hispanic young scholars to advance their research in the rapidly growing field of research.

Symposium topics included:

 

  • Synthesis and Materials Science of magnetic quantum materials, exploration of new air-stable room temperature 2D quantum magnets
  • Novel strategies to tune 2D magnetic order and proximity effects
  • Magneto-optical properties of magnetic 2D materials
  • Multiferroic properties, magnetoelectric effects, spintronic and magnonic transport properties of magnetic 2D materials
  • State-of-the-art experimental probes to directly characterize 2D magnetism
  • Theoretical developments and computational methodologies of low-dimensional magnetic materials and heterostructures
  • Novel magnetism in twisted bilayer graphene, magnetic topological insulators (such as MnBi(2)Te(4)), and Weyl semimetals
 
 
 
 
 
 

 

Activities/Findings/Highlights

This symposium was held at the 2022 Hybrid Spring Meeting of the Materials Research Society, from from May 18th through May 25. The symposium was composed of 8 sessions over 3 days. It also had a Young Scientist Tutorial session on May 08, 2022.

 

Highlights and findings include:

The tutorial (Tutorial QT06?Recent Developments on the Properties of Emergent Layered 2D Quantum Magnetic Materials and Heterostructures) was very useful for young and emerging researchers in this field as it is the second of its kind in MRS Spring Meetings on 2D materials. The success of this tutorial was reflected in the record number (42) of participants.

Summary

The NSF grant funding was used to (1) Support 1 undergraduate, 2 graduate Hispanic (including female) students toward their registration fee; (2) Support 1 female invited speaker for her registration fee; (3) Support 2 symposium organizers (including a female) for their registration fee and travel.

Modified by: J. Ardie Butch Dillen
